As to the question of what MIME types are
available and how/whether to use them, I think
that comes in the category we discussed earlier:
How do we describe a REST resource.  If I remember
correctly, the best proposal on this was yours!

-Alex-

On Mon, 3 Mar 2003, Jeffrey Winter wrote:

>
> > We should be proliferating mimetypes.  Their purpose is to
> > represent different document expectations.  We should use
> > them that way!
>
> A rich set of MIME types is a good thing, but my issue with relying
> on them for extracting different types of content from a single
> resource comes down to a couple of points:
>
> 1.  How would you even know what content types are available?  If
>     an indeterminate set of representations were associated with
>     a resource, how would you even know what MIME types to chuck at it?
>
> 2.  Different content types may have completely different
>     interfaces.  In my own application I happen to split
>     some types out into "resource-spaces" that support
>     different methods:
>
>        /blog/x/y/z  GET only (HTML document)
>        /rss/x/y/x   GET only (RSS 2.0 document)
>        /xbel/x/y/z  GET, PUT, POST, DELETE (XBEL document)
>
>     It wouldn't feel particularly intuitive to have the available
>     methods change based on the Accept: header or even a query
>     string.
>
>     I could see using a Accept: header to distinguish different RSS
>     types from the resources in the /rss "resource-space" above because
>     they are at least clearly different representations of a similar
>     underlying type, but a unique URL (a la query string?) should be
>     available too. Perhaps the absence of either in the request could
>     result in a 300 Multiple Choices, etc.
>
